passages.text: A look at H225 expectations after recent disappointments, prefer Beiersdorf and Unilever

The Global Beauty segment remained subdued with most players disappointing on top- line during reporting, evidencing that demand challenges are persisting. In this note, we provide an overview of the current market dynamics, with a read- across from global beauty peers, and also assess market expectations for European players post H1. We conclude that the global market growth should remain below historical trends at \(3\%\) . Over H225, we see a measured sequential acceleration in demand driven by China and the US, though signals for both are mixed, with risks of US destocking and China competition rising, while W. Europe may decelerate further. It has been a contrasting earnings season for European beauty players, with exaggerated valuation discrepancies and positioning benefitting L'Oréal the most. Looking into H225 expectations - with the market still expecting a sequential H2 acceleration - we see Beiersdorf offering the most compelling risk/reward into H2 at a valuation of 21x PE26E (16x ex- cash) and 9x EV/EBITDA26E. We also flag our fundamentally positive preference on Unilever (OW) as we see evidence of the reshaping of the portfolio towards Beauty & Personal Care as a driver of value creation. L'Oréal's solid H1 has anchored the stock as a must own stock amid a turbulent reporting, yet we flag H2 consensus has risen further proving a tough hurdle amid still subdued Beauty demand.

- Difficult earnings season, low visibility on H2 acceleration. Overall, CQ225 reporting for beauty companies was mixed – with only one company, Puig Brands, delivering organic top-line growth ahead of consensus amongst EU/US beauty companies. Importantly, the top-line growth decelerated on average to \(0.8\%\) in Q2 vs \(1.1\%\) in Q1 with largely subdued market growth outlook ahead tempered by a mixed US, weak Europe and tick up in China ecosystem (with improving MLC and still weak Asian travel retail). Looking into H225, headline beauty players top-line growth is expected to improve sequentially to \(3 - 4\%\) , a reflection of easier comps, innovation launches and lower impact from destocking. Sequentially, China and the US are expected to improve, though the magnitude of acceleration is unclear given mixed signals for both countries, along with risks from US inventory destocking post tariffs. Conversely, WE consumption may well decelerate further. As such, we believe the performance across companies will likely remain mixed, with low visibility on underlying market demand improvement into H225/H126.

- Sector valuation - contrast widening. Post H1 Overall, the global Beauty sector (aggregate of BEI, Coty, EL, and OR) currently trades at 30x 12m Fwd and 18x EV/EBITDA. While historically Beauty companies have traded at a premium to broader EU Food/HPC peers, the current premium is roughly \(10\%\)-pt ahead of the historical average. Within European peers, Beiersdorf is currently trading at decade-low multiples, while L'Oréal is trading ahead of its historical premium to Food/HPC despite delivering growth in-line with the broader peer group. We prefer Beiersdorf, Puig and Unilever (OW) at attractive valuations to play the Beauty market near term, while we remain Neutral on L'Oréal with rich valuations reflecting strong growth expectations ahead.
- Beiersdorf (OW) - Consensus at low end of topline guide for FY25. After

the lowering of the FY25 guidance at the H125 results, expectations for Consumer have come down, with consensus at the bottom of the \(3 - 4\%\) guidance FY25 at \(3.2\%\) . Overall, we see Q3/Q4 LFL uneven phasing (JPME \(2.9\% /5.9\%\) vs consensus \(3.6\% /5.3\%\) ) though the building blocks should start to reassure from Q3 with Nivea returning to LSD in Q3 along with improved La Prairie and strong Eucerin momentum. We have also taken a cautious approach to FY26 top- line and margin (up 20bps), yet we are now \(2\%\) below consensus suggesting incremental downside may be limited. The stock has de- rated to 21x PE26E (16x ex- cash) and 9x EV/EBITDA26E, at a decades low and now at a discount to the wider European Food/HPC sector, we believe the stock offers a compelling risk reward at current valuation and a lower earnings bar.

- L'Oreal (N) - A tougher H2 hurdle. L'Oreal has continued to re-rate post Q225 with consensus expectations of \(-6\%\) exit run-rate for FY25. This is a high bar amid uncertain developed-market demand. Consensus is expecting \(4.8\%\) LFL in Q3 (vs JPME \(4.2\%\) ) implying \(5.5\%\) underlying (due to 70bps impact of IT launch phasing) well above the \(3.7\%\) delivered in Q2. Read from US peers is cautious on the US market in H2 (potential pull forward in demand from retailers/consumers in H1, increasing promotional intensity), China demand is improving in Luxe but Mass has been more mixed and promotional, Europe growth has continued to normalise with most peers cautioning on underlying market demand, especially in prestige beauty. While the impact from the IT system makes the read on underlying more difficult, we still flag that the rise in H2 expectations along with a mixed market picture in H2 provides a tougher hurdle for the stock at 30x PE26e, 18x EV/EBITDA26e (both ex-SAN).

- Puig (OW) - Compelling Valuation. After delivering a top-line beat in Q225 (only Beauty company to do so), Puig maintained LFL25e guide of \(6 - 8\%\) . While we expect FY guide to be supported by continued launches in H225, we note that we are slightly below consensus on both FY25 and FY26 - JPME \(6.4\% /6.1\%\) , respectively, vs consensus \(6.8\% /6.7\%\) . Fragrances remain the fastest growing category even though peers have mentioned deceleration in demand (US, WE) with unclear impact from raised prices in the US on consumers and retail inventories in the US. Puig should benefit from new fragrances sell-in as well as easier make-up comps. Puig is trading on 14x PE26e and 9x EV/EBITDA26e at roughly a \(50\%\) discount to Beauty peers. We see room for rating upside should management deliver on outperforming the premium beauty market in 2025.

- Unilever (OW) - Compelling valuation with Beauty-led growth. Sustained strong DM performance is expected in H2 and to us is testimony of management actions to reposition the portfolio and execution leading to sustained share gains in a competitive market. We expect Beauty & Wellness to accelerate into H2 supported by China/Indonesia as well as India and sustained momentum in the US. Unilever trades on 16.5x PE 26E and 11.5x EV/EBITDA26E. With high teens ROIC and MSD growth potential, we see substantial upside to creating as Unilever transforms into a HPC player. Unilever's quality delivery - accelerating volumes coupled with margin beat - evidence of improvements in innovation, brand support and execution step up which should underpin MSD MT organic sales and high-teens ROIC are not yet reflected in valuation, in our view.

Overall, CQ225 reporting for beauty companies was mixed - with only one company, Puig Brands, delivering organic top- line growth ahead of estimates amongst EU/US companies. Importantly, the top- line growth decelerated on average to \(0.8\%\) in Q2 vs \(1.1\%\) in Q1 with largely subdued market growth outlook ahead tempered with mixed US, weak Europe and tick up in China ecosystem (with improving MLC and still weak Asian travel retail). Looking into H225, while headline beauty peers top- line growth is expected to improve to \(3 - 4\%\) , we note that this is largely a reflection of easier comps, as on 2yr basis, the beauty growth remains subdued and expected to decelerate further vs H125. As such, we believe the performance across companies will likely remain mixed with low visibility on underlying market demand improvement into H225/H126. We prefer Beiersdorf, Puig and Unilever (OW) at attractive valuations to play Beauty market near term while we remain Neutral on L'Oréal with rich valuations reflecting strong growth expectations ahead.

Key conclusions from Q2 reporting: 1) Sequential improvement in beauty market growth into H2 vs H1 though lots of moving parts leading to low visibility and likely continued mixed performance by companies ahead; Regions: 2) subdued consumer sentiment in US/ Europe, retail inventory issue linger in the US though sequentially improving into CH225 (with sell- out remaining strong) and promotional intensity remain in both regions, Europe weakness in larger markets of France and Germany; 3) ML China showing signs of improvement though high competition in mass market - H225 to benefit from easy comps; 4) Asia Travel Retail remains weak (in terms of consumer conversion) though H2 could witness strong reported growth on comps; 5) Emerging Markets overall healthy - pockets of pressure in LatAm, Middle East, SE Asia. Channels: 6) E- com outperforming brick and mortar across companies with Amazon US in particular doing well and Amazon beauty expansion in Canada/ Europe also supporting growth. Categories: 7) Fragrance and Hair care were cited broadly as strongest categories (even if some moderation witnessed) followed by declining Make- up and deceleration in Skincare (impacted in particular due to Sun); Innovations: 8) Most companies continue to focus on accelerating innovations in H2 though Coty noted consumer fatigue; Pricing: 9) Most companies flagged tactical pricing due to tariffs (\~MSD in the US from Aug) though promotional environment remains intense, limited opportunities for pricing cited elsewhere.

Mainland China demand exhibiting early signs of stabilizationMainland China beauty demand is showing signs of modest stabilisation/sequential improvement as per most companies exposed to the region - L'Oréal highlighting that the Luxe segment is outperforming Mass within the region. While Q225 was supported by a robust 618 shopping festival performance, the pace of acceleration remains gradual despite easy comps ahead.

Key conclusions: 1) Luxe is outperforming Mass within MLC as per L'Oréal; 2) Domestic companies outperforming in mass market channels; 3) Sequential improvement in consumption expected by most peers though with cautious optimism. 4) Chinese Beauty peers have reported a miss on Q225 top line with Proya highlighting the industry is "facing the rapidly changing external market." Proya reported \(+6.5\%\) revenue growth in Q225 (vs. \(+13.6\%\) BBG consensus) while Botanee reported \(-16.7\%\) revenue growth (vs. \(+8.2\%\) BBG consensus). Giant Biogene reported \(22.5\%\) revenue growth in H125 while citing "challenging external factors" in Q225 and "tumultous H125".
Key comments from beauty players from CQ225 calls:

L'Oréal: "618: market advanced around \(7\%\) (we were at \(+10\%\) ). Our brands were up double digits". "H2 will be much more favorable in terms of comparable because last year's H2 was much more difficult. Last year H1 market was at \(- 2\%\) and \(- 4\%\) for FY24"
Estee Lauder: "FY26 outlook assumes MSD sales growth in MLC"; "MLC reported HSD growth in Q1/Q2C25 (vs market \(\sim\) MSD)"

Coty: "China beauty market is gradually improving with Prestige Beauty specifically in the June quarter, positive for the first time in many, plus \(3\%\) , and outperformance from the fragrance category at \(7\%\) "; "Lancaster is now growing super, super strongly in China...3- 4x the market"
Beiesdorf: "feel more positive about China"; "Luxe sell- out was \(3\%\) "
PG: "China continuing on its path to growth, not quite there"; "[China] hasn't returned to growth, but its trajectory is positive. It's more balanced across channels than we've seen in the past"

Unilever: "In China, we are seeing improvements to run rates as a result of our significant interventions in our key brand innovation plans, in channel distribution and in pricing execution"; "comfortable with how China is progressing"

LVMH: "local demand in Europe and in the U.S., and a tangible sequential improvement when it comes to Mainland China in the second quarter"; "On China, yes, we have seen tangible improvement locally. We've seen that in Q2 mainly, and this has been driven also by some initiatives and some repatriation of the big drop that we've been seeing in touristic demand from Japan. So, overall, it has improved a few points in terms of growth. It's still negative, but it's high- single- digit negative and much improved"

Asian travel retail consumer dynamics continue to face challenges, with Hainan tourists visit down \(\sim 25\%\) YTD reflecting on lower volume though total value sales (all products) are down \(\sim 7 - 8\%\) helped by higher pricing. Further, growth in other key
tourism markets like Japan and Korea are also showing signs of slowdown on strong comps from last year (boosted by FX).

Key conclusions: Most companies flagged ongoing weakness in the channel which had led to inventory cleanup over the past quarters though H225 is expected to witness a return to growth on significantly easier comparatives.
Key comments from beauty players from CQ225 calls:
L'Oréal: "market in Asia is still negative in high teens"; "Hainan, despite being pretty heavy in traffic, remains very negative in the minus 25- ish in terms of sellout"
Estee Lauder: "- 28% driven by strategic decisions and prolonged weak conversion (15% of revenue now). "Hainan turned positive in May", expanding TR in Americas in F26

Coty: "Our sales in Travel Retail Americas and in the EMEA region are growing nicely...still heavily affected is the Asian Travel Retail, which is heavily linked to the Chinese consumption"- "Asian- Chinese Travel Retail region is hopefully going to come back to a little bit more dynamism"
Beiersdorf: "very difficult environment..., travel retail China, which is minus 18% the market, we are at zero"

LVMH: "Euro's trends penalized touristic purchases in Europe in Q2, whereas the U.S. region improved modestly. In Asia, the impact of tourism is much more significant, as Japan benefited from exceptional demand last year, driven by the yen weakness, and we saw the reversal of this in Q2"
Figure 8: S.Korea and Japan: Monthly Duty Free Sales, yly
Source: Korea Duty Free Shops Association and Japan Department Store Association
Figure 9: Hainan: Monthly Duty Free Sales, yly
Source: Haikou Customs

Key conclusions: 1) Growth in the US bottomed in Q125 with modest improvement in Q2 against market expectations of \(\sim\) MSD with sell- out at \(\sim 2 - 3\%\) ; 2) differentiated performances in channels as Online (led by Amazon Beauty) continues to perform well while offline and department stores remain weak; 3) Retailer inventory destocking remains a theme as the gap in sell- in/sell- out only expected to close by end- 25/ early- 26;

4) Fragrance remains key growth driver with Skin decelerating to flat and Make-up negative; 5) Selective pricing from Aug (at \(\sim\) MSD) exposed to European imports, e.g. Fragrances though promotional intensity remains prevalent.
Key comments from beauty players from CQ225 calls:

L'Oréal: "recent green shoots in the US., including in makeup"; "market growth accelerated, ... flattish in Q1, closer to a \(+2 - 3\%\) in Q2"; "Luxury remains slightly positive...Dermo is positive... but slowed vs last year...salon market remains sluggish, but selective or online is extremely dynamic"

Estee Lauder: "ended fiscal '25 with \(- 5\% - \mathrm{pt}\) gap between retail and net sales growth for the full-year. While we expect the gap to narrow throughout the year, a greater disconnect is anticipated in the first quarter"

Coty: "US prestige beauty market grew by \(\sim 4\%\) in FY25"..."US mass beauty market declined by \(\sim 1\%\) "; "Prestige Fragrance ... market trends are incrementally stronger in FQ4 compared to FQ3"; "Mass cosmetics category saw a sharper category slowdown from +HSD in F24 to - MSD in FQ3 and - LSD in FQ4
Beiersdorf: "[Luxe] market in the US ...negative in Q2"
Puig: "In Q2, the region [Americas] maintain its momentum, delivering net revenue of EUR416 million, reflecting \(10\%\) LFL growth"
LVMH: "American demand overall is broadly unchanged, a bit less"; "we had a better performance and an acceleration of growth at Sephora, so that played a role there [US performance]"
Interparfums: Tariff uncertainty though strong growth in H1 (+20% organic growth); Expect tougher H225
Western Europe showing increasing signs of strain, especially in Luxe

Key conclusions: 1) Largely cautious commentary from companies with growth slowing on easing pricing; 2) Larger France, German markets with weaker growth while S. Europe remains positive; 3) increasing promotional environment with pressure from retailers and consumers
Key comments from beauty players from CQ225 calls:

L'Oréal: "Europe sell-out was around \(4\%\) growth in H1...LDB impacted by Sun"; "We are broadly in line with the European market, above in three divisions and slightly below in CPD and with a pretty strong plan on the H2."

Estee Lauder: from CH224 to CH125, "we did see slowdown in Europe"; "we are seeing a decrease in consumer sentiment, and obviously a little bit of a softening of the trend, especially in the key markets like France, Germany, and to a lesser extent in Italy and Spain"
Coty: "gained or held share across Europe, the Middle East, APAC, South Africa, Brazil, and global travel retail"
Beiersdorf: "Impact from delistings in Europe was 2%- pt...that will go to approximately zero in Q3, Q4"

Puig: "In line with Q1, the region [Europe] saw slower growth rates compared to 2024 following an extended period of high growth levels. We continue to see mixed performance across this region, with continued softness in markets such as France"
Interparfums: Good momentum in W. Europe (UK, Spain and Germany doing well) and Poland. France remained weak with market volume down 5% and value down 3%.

Douglas: "premium beauty market has shown a significant slowdown in this year but in our 22 European markets is growing around 3%. France, that's our number two market, is the only market which actually really showed a decline. And in the German market, we basically see year- to- date a flattish development." "expect a continuation of the current promotional environment, and the likelihood that it will be more promotional is higher than it will be less promotional."

Scanner data for beauty category growth in US/ W. Europe continues to show ongoing deceleration into Jul/Aug- 25 in terms of value growth with pricing normalising with signs of promotional intensity picking up. Volume growth in the US is down \(\sim 1\%\) on average YTD while W. Europe has been healthy at \(\sim\) MSD helped by \(\sim 1.2\%\) pricing. Parsing through the categories: a) Fragrance remains healthy at low- teens% in the US in L12wk, Make- up remains negative and Skin care flattish. Within W. Europe: Make- up is declining- MSD while Skin care and Hair care remain healthy at \(+\) MSD.

Overall, EMs continue to be growth driver though with pockets of weakness, e.g. Brazil/ Mexico and LatAm and Middle East impacted by ongoing geopolitical environment. Tariff uncertainty hangs over EM consumption especially in SE Asia though companies have maintained positive outlook for EM growth into H225.
Key comments from beauty players from CQ225 calls:

L'Oréal: "The large markets all grew, the vast majority above \(10\%\) "; "Latin America remains pretty dynamic, slowed down a bit, particularly in Mexico,...So the underlying market growth has slowed down from low teens in 2024 to a high single digit in the first half"
Estee Lauder: "intend to be in double- digit growth"; "Japan remains strong though slowing with less tourists, Korea soft"
Coty: "In Asia, excluding China, our sellout grew \(\sim 4x\) ahead of market growth"

Beiersdorf: "Market growth, especially in the emerging markets, was slower than expected due to broader economic uncertainties, geopolitical effects, and a lower consumer confidence." "declining in Brazil...hit particularly on deodorants"
Puig: "strong performances in South Korea and Japan, we'll have newer subsidiaries. This was further complimented by increased local activations for Charlotte Tilbury in Australia and China"
Interparfums: Japan doing well while Australia/ Korea have been weak. Middle East was weak in H1 impacted by geopolitical impact on point of sales
Unilever: "We see an acceleration of growth in the second half with sustained performance in developed markets and improvement in emerging markets, particularly in India, Indonesia and China."
Categories: Fragrance remains star performer, Make- up weakest

Overall, Fragrance remains the solid performer amongst beauty categories supported by favorable market dynamics as well as new launches across peers. Hair care continue to do well though salons visits were weaker and online continues to outperform. Skincare decelerated (partly on weak Sun) while Make- up remains weak.
Key comments from beauty players from CQ225 calls:

L'Oréal: "skin care is the category impacted chiefly by the discrepancy between sell- in and sell- out and the sun care stocking of last year"; "Fragrances & Hair care remain fastest growth categories"
Estee Lauder: CQ225 "reflecting declines across all categories except fragrance"; "Fragrance is the category poised to lead prestige beauty industry globally in fiscal '26"

Coty: "Our analysis of cosmetics category weakness points to value- seeking behaviour, some fatigue with innovation as consumers circle back to basics and less frequent usage, particularly with Gen Z migrating to fragrances"; "Skincare market was \(\sim 3\%\) and Coty outperformed with \(11\%\) "; "Niche, which is above \(\) 150\(is growing by\) 14\% \(and everything under\) \ \(50\) is growing by \(11\%\) . These two parts of the markets are the fastest growing."
Puig: "Fragrance market, our best estimation of the growth of the fragrance market which continues to be healthy is in the mid- single- digit range"

Overall, Beauty sector (aggregate of BEI, Coty, EL, and OR) currently trades at 30x 12m Fwd PE and 18x EV/EBITDA. While historically, Beauty companies have traded at premium to broader EU Food/HPC peers, current premium is roughly \(10\% - pt\) ahead of historical average. Within European peers, Beiersdorf is currently trading at decade low multiples while L'Oreal is trading ahead of its historical premium to Food/HPC despite delivering growth in- line with broader peer group.

After the lowering of the FY25 guidance at H125 results, expectations for Consumer have come down with consensus at the bottom of the \(3 - 4\%\) guidance FY25 at \(3.2\%\) . The stock has continued to de- rate as we believe a) Nivea recovery uncertain with likely pricing pressure ahead and b) market may discount that \(3 - 4\%\) growth outlook is still too ambitious while pathway into FY26 remains uncertain.

JPM view: we take a more measured approach to Q3/Q4 phasing (slower Q3/strong Q4) given the phasing of innovation in Nivea (Epicelline) and China recovery will be more impactful to Q4 - hence our above consensus forecast for Q4.

1) Focus on WE beauty and Nivea recovery: Market value growth has remained at \(\sim \mathrm{MSD}\) per recent Nielsen data (until mid-July) with growth led by Sun care while core Skin and Personal care categories were weak. Overall market share data stabilised - again led by Sun care. Key focus on core Skin care markets ahead - as we note weak volumes (L12wk until mid-July) in France (down MSD) and Germany (down HSD) though partly offset by +MSD in UK and low-teens growth in Italy. With delistings impact (200bps in W. Europe) behind us, we expect W. Europe growth to sequentially improve into H225.

2) Consumer margin - while management lowered FY25 guide to \(+20\) bps (vs \(+50\) bps earlier), we remain prudent into FY26 with JPMc \(+20\) bps vs consensus \(+40\) bps though we believe investor expectations are muted. Overall, JPMc \(2\%\) below consensus EPS25/26e.

3) Innovation: With strong innovation led growth in Derma (and Nivea Face), the delivery of innovation led growth for Nivea (Epicelline) in Europe will be key for growth ahead. We expect Q425/ FY26 to be further supported by China Thiamidol, US Epicelline and EMs innovations along with relaunch of Deodorants franchise across markets.

After the lowering of the FY25 guidance at H125 results, expectations for Consumer have come down with consensus at the bottom of the \(3 - 4\%\) guidance FY25 at \(3.2\%\) . Overall, we see Q3/Q4 LFL uneven phasing (JPMc \(2.9\% /5.9\%\) vs consensus \(3.6\% /5.3\%\) ) though the building blocks should start to reassure from Q3 with Nivea returning to LSD in Q3 along with improved La Prairie and strong Eucerin momentum.

We have also taken a cautious approach to FY26 top line and margin (up 20bps) yet we are now \(2\%\) below consensus suggesting incremental downside may be limited. The stock has de- rated to 21x PE26E (16x ex- cash) and 9x EV/EBITDA26E, at decades low and now at a discount to the wider European Food/HPC sector, we believe the stock offers a compelling risk reward at valuation and a lower earnings bar.

L'Oréal management offered the most positive comments about market growth acceleration in H2 to \(- 5\%\) (leading to \(- 4\%\) beauty market growth for FY25) with broadbased positive comments across markets - improving US, strong Europe sell- out, acceleration in MLC and healthy EMs. The stock has continued to re- rate post Q225 with consensus expectations of \(- 6\%\) exit run- rate for FY25.

JPM view: we take a more measured approach to demand in Europe which has continued to slow with most peers/retailers flagging weak growth in the larger French/ German markets and rising promotional intensity ahead. While US rebound in Q2 was stronger than expected amid support from Amazon beauty, we believe this is largely reflected in expectations now even as imbalances remain in sell- in/sell- out as the company flagged c200bps of IT sell- in in Q324 in the USA. With multiple IT system impacts, the visibility on underlying performance has lowered.

1) High bar amid uncertain developed markets demand: Consensus is expecting \(4.8\%\) LFL in Q3 (vs JPMc \(4.2\%\) ) implying \(5.5\%\) underlying (due to 70bps impact of IT launch phasing) well above the \(3.7\%\) delivered in Q2 which looks demanding. We remain below consensus on Europe. The US recovery is the clear driver of CEO Hieronimus's optimism as he noted the sequential acceleration, while being optimistic about H2 performance. The US could also benefit from tariffs related pricing though it is unclear if H1 has seen some pull forward in demand from retailers/consumers while peers are also flagging lingering destocking in the coming quarters. Additionally, we believe increasing promotional intensity may likely lead to lower realisation in net pricing support. Europe growth has continued to normalise with most peers cautioning on underlying market demand, especially in prestige beauty while consensus is baking in a re-acceleration that may be demanding.

2) China ecosystem: Improving growth momentum, albeit gradual, should support growth into H225e though competition from local players in Mass and international brands in Prestige is increasing. Besides, Asia travel retail remains weak though we expect strong rebound in reported growth given inventory clean-up in comparable base ahead. Overall, we expect \(-4\%\) LFL in N. Asia in H2 vs Consensus \(-4.5\%\) .

3) Emerging Markets: Overall steady at \(\sim\) HSD though pockets of concerns with slowdown in Brazil/Mexico and Middle East while SE Asia demand remains uncertain amid overall tariff impact on consumers.

At \(30x\) PE26e, \(18x\) EV/EBITDA26e (both ex- SAN), L'Oréal's valuation remains ahead of peers - a premium which remains elevated in the face of a MT growth rate of JPME \(4 - 5\%\) . In the near term, the inline H1 delivery has supported the re- rating driven by hopes of improvement in the US and China. While the impact from IT system makes the read on underlying more difficult, we still flag that the rise in H2 expectations along with a mixed market picture in H2 provides a tougher hurdle for the stock.

After delivering top- line beat in Q225 (only Beauty company to do so), Puig maintained LFL25e guide of \(6 - 8\%\) . While we expect FY guide to be supported by continued launches in H225, we note that we are slightly below consensus on both FY25 and FY26 - JPM \(6.4\% /6.1\%\) respectively vs consensus \(6.8\% /6.7\%\) .

JPM view: H2 growth is expected to be be supported by already announced \~MSD price increases in the US along with new fragrance launches like La Bomba, and Niche collections with Byredo and L'Artisan Parfumeur. In an uncertain macro backdrop and beauty demand, we believe Puig delivery remains solid though we note that Puig and peers have commented on moderation in Fragrance market growth in the USA and WE, as well as possible inventory destocking in the USA. We note that despite concerns on Fragrances moderation, Puig should benefit from innovation launches as well as easier comparatives in Make up.

1) Focus on underlying market and pricing: Fragrance remains the fastest growing category across W. European/ US markets across niche/ prestige and mass channels. As peers continue to guide for gradual moderation in the category, focus will remain on launches ahead of key festive season. Additionally, most Fragrance peers have European manufacturing base for Fragrance with many implementing \~MSD pricing from Aug in the US even as net realisation will depend on the promotional environment as noted by Coty.

2) Margin - We continue to expect adj EBITDA margin \(+20\) bps, in-line with guidance of 'Adj EBITDA margin improvement similar as FY24', i.e. 20bps. Yet, we expect flat EBIT margin with higher D&A weighing given higher CapEx - which we believe is yet to be reflected in market expectations.

Puig is trading on 14x PE26e and 9x EV/EBITDA26e at roughly \(50\%\) discount to Beauty peers. We see room for rating upside should management deliver on outperforming the premium beauty market in 2025.

Consensus expectations of \(c6\%\) LFL in H225e remain well anchored in our view (JPM \(5.4\%\) ) as management continues to build a track record of consistent delivery. The stock continues to trade at attractive multiples and we see a path to re- rating over a period of time with consistency in growth despite concerns on Fragrance moderation ahead. Amid a bumpy 2025 for beauty market, we believe Puig remains best placed to deliver the fastest top- line growth (albeit normalising) amongst EU Staples which should support stock re- rating as management builds a track record of consistent execution.

Management delivered a confident message with organic sales growth improving in H2, driven by self- help initiatives in Beauty & Wellbeing and in India, Indonesia and China.

JPM view: Sustained strong DM performance is expected in H2 and to us is testimony of management actions to reposition the portfolio and execution leading to sustained share gains in a competitive market. We expect Beauty & Wellness to accelerate into H2 supported by China/ Indonesia as well as India and sustained momentum in the US. We expect top- line growth to improve further through the year to JPM \(\mathrm{e}4.5\%\) LFL in H2 (progressively improving with \(+4.1\%\) in Q3 and \(+4.9\%\) in Q4). This should be led by Core business volumes, which we see picking up from \(1.1\%\) in H1 to \(2.2\%\) in H2 - and underpinned by sustained competitive growth in DMs whilst EMs accelerate on easier comparatives and operational improvements. Overall, we are \(1\% /2\%\) ahead of consensus EPS25/26e, respectively.

1) Sustained momentum in DMs: Nielsen data continues to support sustained growth momentum in the US and W. Europe in July with share gains across Beauty, Personal Care and Foods (ex Ice cream) categories.
2) China / Indonesia: sequential improvement into Q3/Q4 is key to accelerate momentum with improving alignment in consumption and sell-in ahead as well as support from easy comps.

3) Margin delivery: After a strong H1, Unilever expects \(18.5\% +\) operating margin in H2, driven by growth leverage, higher productivity and intervention in the value chain of key materials, albeit with a bit of an uptick in costs in H2 vs H1. Investment in BMI at \(15 - 16\%\) of sales is reaffirmed as the right level.

Unilever trades on 16.5x PE 26E and 11.5x EV/EBITDA 26E. With high teens ROIC and MSD growth potential we see substantial upside to rerating as Unilever transforms into a HPC player. Unilever's quality delivery - accelerating volumes coupled with margin beat and raise - evidences improvements in innovation, brand support and execution step up which should underpin MSD MT organic sales and high-teens ROIC are not yet reflected in valuation.

Beiersdorf (Overweight; Price Target: €140.00)

We believe Beiersdorf has turned into a solid growth engine, realising the growth potential of Nivea while fortifying pillars of growth in its Dermatology and Luxe brands. We expect Beiersdorf's structural transformation of growth momentum (driving 5- 6% growth in Consumer MT) and MT margin target of at least 50bps pa (Consumer) should also help narrow the valuation gap with Beauty and HPC peers.
We set our DCF- derived Dec- 26 target price at €140 with a WACC of 8.5% and LT growth of \(+3\%\) .

L'Oreal (Neutral; Price Target: €360.00)

We rate L'Oreal Neutral as we see the company's mid- term growth at \(4 - 5\%\) at odds with a premium rating amid an uncertain global Beauty market. Near term, support from US market demand should address top- line weakness concerns though we retain our mid- term top- line growth forecasts at \(4 - 5\%\) , modestly outperforming the global beauty market facing normalisation in Europe and an uncertain N. Asia. As top line growth gap narrows vs Europe staples peers, we believe L'Oreal's premium rating will remain at risk..
We set a Dec- 26 DCF- derived Target Price of €360 (WACC of \(8.5\%\) ; LT growth rate of \(3.5\%\) ).

Puig Brands (Overweight; Price Target: €25.00)

Puig offers a compelling structural growth story in the context of European Staples with a portfolio exposed to an underlying market of JPMecMSD- HSD%. It is a play on the current boom in global fragrances - 4th player worldwide - along with the exposure to faster- growing niche super- premium fragrances, prestige make- up and the skin dermatology market. We see Puig positioned to outgrow the Beauty market thanks to a portfolio of owned "love brands" geared to the faster- growing ultra- premium fragrances market and with substantial white- space opportunities in Makeup, Skin Care and internationalization. Management has continued to highlight its confidence in outperforming the premium beauty market (growth at \(6 - 7\%\) ) into 2025. Amid a likely bumpy 2025 for the beauty market, we believe Puig remains best placed to deliver the fastest top- line growth (albeit normalising) amongst EU Staples which should support stock re- rating as management builds a track record of consistent execution. We expect \(8\%\) LFL and \(12\%\) adj net profit CAGR23- 26e, in line with management targets of high- single- digit top- line growth in the mid- term, coupled with improving adj EBITDA margin.
We set a DCF- derived Dec- 26 PT of €25.
